docs.lead_paragraph: The national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association suggested yesterday that Ohio Blue Cross and Blue Shield was not getting full value for the main business lines that it has agreed to sell to the Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corporation for $299.5 million. The board of the national association said that it was concerned about the ''unorthodox closed-door process'' that resulted in the deal that was announced last March. The board also questioned the $19 million that Columbia agreed to pay Ohio Blue Cross executives.

headline.main: Blue Cross Questions Purchase Of Ohio Plan by Columbia-HCA

docs.abstract: National Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association suggests that Ohio Blue Cross and Blue Shield is not getting full value for main business lines it will sell to Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corp for $299.5 million; national association's board also questions $19 million that Columbia has agreed to pay Ohio Blue Cross executives; concerns have also been raised by Ohio Atorney General, Betty Montgomery; Ohio Attorney General and state insurance department have joined suit by Blue Cross policyholders calling for an independent board to set value of Ohio health plan (M)
docs.snippet: The national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association suggested yesterday that Ohio Blue Cross and Blue Shield was not getting full value for the main business lines that it has agreed to sell to the Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corporation for $299.5...

docs.lead_paragraph: Deal on Mental Health May Affect Employers Experts on employee benefits said Congress's decision to expand health insurance coverage for the mentally ill would prompt tens of thousands of businesses to redesign their employee health benefits in ways that go far beyond what is required by Congress. Employers, even big companies like Xerox and Hewlett-Packard, said they feared that the new requirements would substantially increase their costs. $(Page 1.$) Stocks Rise But Dow Misses Record Stocks were mostly higher, lifting some measures to record highs, but the buying was restrained with many investors awaiting next week's Federal Reserve policy meeting on interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 20.72 points, to 5,888.46, closing less than a point from Monday's record close of 5,889.20. The Nasdaq composite index rose for the 11th consecutive session, led again by technology issues. $(34.$) Prices of Treasury securities rose as dealers and traders squared positions ahead of the Fed's meeting. The yield on the 30-year bond was unchanged at 7.04 percent. $(34.$) Archer Daniels Sues Executive Archer Daniels Midland has sued Mark E. Whitacre, the former company executive who served as an informant for the Government, accusing him of embezzling millions of dollars from the company over several years. Mr. Whitacre, who secretly tape-recorded meetings as part of a price-fixing investigation of Archer Daniels, was dismissed from the company last year amid allegations of embezzlement. He has acknowledged obtaining the money in overseas bank accounts. But he has said that he obtained it as part of a secret plan intended to allow executives to avoid taxes; Archer Daniels denies that allegation. $(43.$) Blue Cross Questions Deal The national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association suggested that Ohio Blue Cross and Blue Shield was not getting full value for the main business lines that it has agreed to sell to the Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corporation for $299.5 million. $(43.$) Time Warner in Feud With Fox Time Warner's cable television company has decided to offer NBC's new news channel and not one being started by Rupert Murdoch's Fox Inc., enraging Fox executives, who accused the Time Warner chairman, Gerald Levin, of breaking a fully negotiated agreement. One Fox executive said that Mr. Murdoch was so angry over the decision that Fox may retaliate. $(21.$) F.T.C. Drops Publishing Case Seventeen years after starting an antitrust investigation, the Federal Trade Commission quietly closed a case involving six of the largest book publishers without deciding if they ever discriminated against independent bookstores by selling discounted books to major chains. Voting 3 to 1 to end the antitrust review, the commission released a statement explaining that it was better to terminate the case because it did not appear to be a ''prudent use of scarce public resources.'' $(32.$) Funeral Home Rivals Fight The shooting began between the two largest funeral home chains in the country after the Service Corporation, which is seeking to buy the Loewen Group, said its rival had overpaid when it spent $240 million to buy the nation's largest cemetery and funeral home. $(32.$) Dollar Rises Slightly The dollar was moderately higher against major currencies as traders squared their books before the European finance ministers' meeting this weekend in Dublin and the Fed's session on Tuesday. In late New York trading, the dollar stood at 1.5155 marks, up from 1.5132 on Thursday. The dollar traded at 109.80 Japanese yen, up from 109.40. $(33.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: International 2-5 TURKEY URGES ON IRAQ Determined to crack down on Turkish Kurds who are waging a guerrilla war from camps in northern Iraq, Turkey is urging Iraq to reimpose authority there. 1 JAPAN'S IMPERIAL DRAMA When Masako Owada became Japan's Crown Princess three years ago, she was a symbol of modernity; now she is judged by a standard that is thousands of years old -- her ability to bear a son. 1 U.S. FLIGHTS OVER IRAN BARRED The Federal Aviation Administration has issued an emergency order barring flights by United States airlines over Iran because, it said, the Iranians installed antiaircraft missiles on their border. 2 Recent Swiss banking scandals have forced a soul-searching. 3 An investigation is ordered into reports of contra drug-trafficking. 3 Yeltsin's medical condition may complicate his operation. 4 Bosnian election results have fed some hope of reconciliation. 4 Street Journal: A new schoolboy named Boris Yeltsin. 4 National 6-10 CLINTON PREFERENCE SEEN Four-dozen long interviews with voters at their homes in Raleigh, N.C., and York, Pa., suggest that Bill Clinton leads in national polls, simply put, because he means more things to more people. 1 HEALTH PLANS TO BE REDESIGNED? Experts on employee benefits said that the recent decision by Congress to expand health insurance coverage for the mentally ill would prompt tens of thousands of businesses to redesign their health plans in ways that go far beyond what is required by Congress. 1 KACZYNSKI JOURNALS DISCLOSED A Federal prosecutor disclosed that Theodore Kaczynski, the Unabom suspect, had kept detailed, daily journals with entries along the lines of, ''I mailed that bomb,'' and ''I sent that bomb.'' 1 NEW LEADER ENTHRONED A new era for Greek Orthodox Christians in the United States begins when Archbishop Spyridon is enthroned as their first American-born prelate. 6 REPUBLICANS TO MOVE ON FILES House Republicans who have been investigating how the Clinton White House improperly acquired confidential F.B.I. files plan to call on the bureau's general counsel to resign over his role in the matter. 7 LUCID LOOKS AHEAD After an extended stay in space, Dr. Shannon Lucid said she looked forward to family and gooey desserts when she returns home. 6 ACCUSATIONS ON ETHICS PANEL The senior Democrat on the House ethics committee accused the Republicans who control it of burying charges against Speaker Newt Gingrich. 10 LOUISIANA FREE-FOR-ALL Louisiana's law on open primaries has created a political free-for-all as voters in the state go to the polls to elect Senate candidates. 6 CAMPAIGN SHIFTS TO CHARACTER The Presidential campaign shifted to character as the Dole and Clinton camps used the issue of teen-age drug abuse to deliver a broader message about their opponents. 8 POLITICS AND THE IMMIGRATION BILL As House and Senate Republicans struggle to salvage a bill cracking down on illegal immigration that President Clinton will sign, they are reluctantly conceding that what serves their own interests may hurt Bob Dole's campaign. 9 DOLE'S TEMPERED CRITICISM Bob Dole's statements in the wake of Saddam Hussein's actions in northern Iraq underscored the difficulty any Presidential challenger faces in trying to capitalize on a foreign policy crisis without appearing to undercut his own country. 9 NEW GUIDELINES ON TRANSPLANTS Federal health officials proposed new guidelines for transplants of animal organs and tissues into humans, responding to concerns about their potential for causing outbreaks of diseases. 10 Metro Report 21-25 DOWNED JET USED IN BOMB TESTS Adding another twist to the search for the cause of the crash of T.W.A. 800, Federal officials said that the 747 jetliner was used during a test of bomb-detecting dogs six weeks before the crash, which they said could be a possible explanation for the traces of explosives found on the plane's wreckage. 1 Business Digest 31 Arts/Entertainment 11-17 Frescoes of Renaissance master restored in Italy. 11 Museums take stock of Picasso and Homer exhibitions. 16 Music: Masur the modernist. 11 Charlie Haden and Kenny Barron at Iridium. 14 Fiona Apple. 14 A tribute to Jon Hendricks. 16 Television: Sexy versus seemly. 17 Triple dose of paranoia. 17 Sports 26-30 Baseball: Red Sox beat Yanks. 27 Column: Rhoden on Gooden. 27 Football: Giants shake-up their special teams. 30 Whitaker defeats Rivera in a unanimous decision. 29 Obituaries 48 Editorials/Op-Ed 18-19 Editorials Keeping guns out of schools. Foreign aid for family planning. Sunday's stupor bowl. Honesty in banking. Letters Frank Rich: A banished kingdom. Russell Baker: Another species extinct. Bob Devecchi and Bill Frelick: Don't forsake the Kurdish refugees. Mitchell Adams and Nancy Sinsabaugh: Payback on student loans. Arthur Spitzer: Congress plays judge in a custody case. docs.lead_paragraph: Experts on employee benefits said today that Congress's decision to expand health insurance coverage for the mentally ill would prompt tens of thousands of businesses to revise their health plans in ways that go far beyond what is required by Congress. Employers, including big companies like Xerox and Hewlett-Packard, said they feared that the new requirements would substantially increase their costs. But others said the costs would be manageable.

headline.main: EXPERTS FORESEE HEALTH PLAN SHIFT FOR MENTAL CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: With the battle for the House now considered to be extremely competitive, the Democrats have a sensitive task over the next seven weeks: preparing for the possibility of power, and assuring the voters that this would be a Democratic House very different from the one they rejected in the 1994 elections. Already, Republicans are beginning to warn of dire consequences if the Democrats regain their majority, asserting that an array of liberal committee chairmen would quickly revert to the most hidebound big-government agendas of the past.

headline.main: Middle of Road Beckons In Drive to Overtake G.O.P.

docs.abstract: Democrats hope to convince voters that they have mended their liberal ways since 1994 and deserve to regain control of House in upcoming elections; National Republican Congressional Committee is issuing information sheets on potential Democratic committee chairmen called 'The Radical Roster'; but Democrats insist that new Democratic lineup in Congress will be decidedly centrist, attuned to middle class's needs and far more efficient than sprawling federation of fiercely independemt committee chairmen that largely ran Democratic-majority House before 1994 (M)
docs.snippet: With the battle for the House now considered to be extremely competitive, the Democrats have a sensitive task over the next seven weeks: preparing for the possibility of power, and assuring the voters that this would be a Democratic House very...

docs.lead_paragraph: House and Senate leaders announced agreement today on two major health insurance proposals, directing insurance companies to offer comparable coverage for mental and physical illnesses and to guarantee new mothers coverage for at least 48 hours of hospital care after childbirth. President Clinton strongly supports both proposals, so it is highly likely that they will become law. The changes would take effect in January 1998.

headline.main: CONFEREES AGREE ON MORE COVERAGE FOR HEALTH CARE

docs.abstract: House and Senate leaders announce agreement on two major health insurance proposals, directing insurance companies to offer comparable coverage for mental and physical illnesses and to guarantee new mothers coverage for at leat 48 hours of hospital care after childbirth; Pres Clinton supports both proposals and is expected to sign measure, which would take effect in January 1998; new measure would prohibit employers, insurers and health plans from setting lower limits for coverage of mental illness than for physical illness, a common practice under current law; under new law, health plans that provide maternity benefits must include hospital coverage for women and their newborns for at least 48 hours after normal vaginal delivery and 96 hours after Caesarean section; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sumitomo Estimate of Loss Grows in Copper Scandal Sumitomo said the losses incurred by Yasuo Hamanaka, its former chief copper trader, had increased to $2.6 billion, $800 million higher than earlier, and that it would request that criminal charges be filed against him. Much uncertainty remained, but Sumitomo seemed to be trying to put the scandal behind it, giving few details of how the trader could have hidden such losses or whether others might have cooperated with him. $(Page D3.$) Showdown Over Wireless Taps The wireless communications industry voted to reject Government-backed technology that would make it possible for law enforcement agencies to keep closer tabs on cellular telephone users. $(A1.$) Fraud Charges Against Merrill Seen Merrill Lynch has been told by regulators that they intend to charge it with disclosure fraud in connection with the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., lawyers said. $(D2.$) A Big Gain In Construction Builders broke ground on new homes and apartments at the fastest rate in nearly two and a half years during August. Housing starts, which were predicted to decline modestly, instead increased 4.5 percent. $(D2.$) After the housing report, bond yields rose because of fears of rising inflation and an increase in interest rates by the Fed. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond was 7.04 percent, up from 7.01 percent on Wednesday. $(D13.$) 2 Big Ad-Agency Companies to Join The stampede of acquisitions involving advertising-agency companies continued, but with a twist: the buyer is smaller than the seller. BDDP in Paris, the 15th-largest agency company in the world, agreed to be acquired by GGT in London, the 22d largest. $(D5.$) Settlement in Comparator Case The S.E.C. settled cases against Comparator Systems, a company that had no successful products but that somehow became valued at a billion dollars, and two officials who had been accused of issuing financial reports that overstated the company's assets. Floyd Norris: Market Place.$(D6.$) Group to Buy Ryder Rental Unit Questor Partners Fund and a group of other investors plan to buy Ryder System's rental truck division for about $575 million. $(D16.$) Olivetti's New Chief Carlo de Benedetti may no longer be the chairman of Olivetti, the computer maker, but he remains a powerful shareholder. With this leverage, his representatives on the board ousted the company's chief executive and installed Roberto Colaninno, above, who headed an auto parts company controlled by Mr. de Benedetti. $(D3.$) Insurance Accord In Congress House and Senate leaders agreed on two major health insurance proposals, directing insurance companies to offer comparable coverage for mental and physical illnesses and to guarantee mothers coverage for at least 48 hours of hospital care after childbirth. $(A20.$) I.B.M. said it would provide benefits to the partners of lesbian and gay employees. It is the largest employer yet to extend health care coverage to couples of the same sex. $(A18.$) Barneys Parent Seeks to End Deal The parent company of Barneys New York, which filed for bankruptcy protection last January, said it was seeking to end a licensing agreement with its partner, Isetan. $(D6.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: International A3-16 A PEACE PACT IN GUATEMALA Moving decisively toward ending the longest guerrilla war in the Western Hemisphere, the Guatemalan Government and leftist rebels signed a peace accord. A1 ''An absurd conflict'' that lasted 35 years and left 100,000 dead. A16 ISLAMIC BACKLASH HITS IRAN In the midst of a backlash against the gradual loosening of restrictions on politics, education, and social activities, a heated debate gripping Iran is whether women should be permitted to ride bicycles. A1 NORTH KOREAN AGENTS SLAIN South Korean troops shot and killed seven North Korean commandos, but at least one of the group that sneaked ashore from a submarine remained at large. A3 G.I.'S RETURN TO KUWAIT As has happened many times before, hundreds of Army troops who traveled nearly nonstop from the United States were on their way to new posts in Kuwait. A6 HANDING OVER NUCLEAR BUTTON Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin will control Russia's nuclear arsenal when President Boris N. Yeltsin has heart surgery. A8 Along with prosperity, discontent also rises in Thailand. A3 Israel acts to expand West Bank and Gaza Strip settlements. A5 Pope John Paul II began a touchy visit to France. A9 Germany said its 320,000 Bosnian refugees should go home. A14 Cape Town Journal: Drugs and vigilante justice in South Africa. A4 National A18-29 AGREEMENT ON HEALTH BILLS House and Senate leaders announced agreement on two major health insurance proposals, directing insurance companies to offer comparable coverage for mental and physical illnesses and to guarantee new mothers coverage for at least 48 hours of hospital care after childbirth. A1 HOUSE VOTES TO OVERRIDE VETO With three votes to spare, members voted 285 to 137 to overturn President Clinton's veto of a ban on the procedure critics call ''partial-birth'' abortion and doctors call ''intact dilation and extraction.'' A22 CELLULAR SHOWDOWN The wireless communications industry voted to reject technology that would make it possible for law-enforcement agencies to keep closer tabs on cellular phone users. A1 EXPOSURE TO CHEMICALS DETAILED While the Pentagon continues to insist that it has no evidence that American troops were made sick from exposure to Iraqi chemical weapons during the 1991 gulf war, veterans of a naval reserve battalion have offered details of an incident that has left them ill. A1 DOLE STAYS CALM IN TOUGH TIMES Having endured what may well have been one of the worst stretches of Presidential politicking in recent history, Bob Dole has remained, by all accounts, calm, unflappable and even chipper. A1 BENEFITS FOR GAY PARTNERS IBM announced that it would provide benefits for the partners of lesbian and gay employees beginning in January. A18 POLIO VACCINE REINSTATED Inactivated polio vaccine, known to millions in the 1950's and 60's as the Salk vaccine, was reinstated as part of the Federal Government's recommended schedule of childhood immunizations. A18 SIMPSON TRIAL BEGINS AGAIN As the civil trial of O.J. Simpson got under way in Santa Monica, Calif., many people agreed on the sentiment: Not again. A18 CAMPAIGNING BY BUS The Clintons and Gores rolled their trademark buses along the byways of the Pacific Northwest, bashing the Republicans in town after town and calling for Democrats to be elected to Congress. A29 HOUSE ELECTION SCENARIOS With the battle for the House now considered extremely competitive, Democrats and Republicans alike are offering their versions of what the Congress would look like if the Democrats regain control. A29 NEW DEBATE STRATEGY Senior Clinton campaign aides said they were considering finding a sponsor for a debate that would include Ross Perot. A29 Metro Report B1-6 THE MAN BEHIND THE TRANSIT UNION Willie James, leader of New York City's transit workers' union, had made the grim decision to let the Transit Authority put welfare recipients to work cleaning subways and buses. But as contract talks wound down this week, he wanted something in return: to give them a head start toward permanent jobs. Anthony Lewis: Dole inside out. Sara Mosle: In school, but not learning. Chronicle D20 Crossword C27

docs.lead_paragraph: In their first two debates here this week, Senator Paul Wellstone repeatedly called his Republican opponent, former Senator Rudy Boschwitz, a ''cheerleader for the Gingrich agenda.'' Just as often, Mr. Boschwitz called Mr. Wellstone ''ultra-liberal'' or ''embarrassingly liberal.''

headline.main: Democrats Fight Hard In Key Midwest Races

docs.abstract: Article discusses campaigns of candidates in key Midwestern states, including Senate races in Minnesota, South Dakota, Iowa, Michigan, Nebraska, Illinois and Kansas (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Seven years ago when Seymour Sternberg was recruited to join the New York Life Insurance Company he figured he might have a shot at some day running it. In July, after nearly 10 months as New York Life's No. 2 in command, he began to think he was pretty much there. And yesterday, the 15-member board made it official: effective next April, he's the new boss, replacing Harry G. Hohn, as chairman and chief executive officer, when Mr. Hohn retires at age 65. Mr. Sternberg will retain his title as president.

headline.main: Big Insurer Promotes President To Chief

docs.abstract: New York Life Insurance Co names its president, Seymour Sternberg, to succeed Harry G Hohn as chairman and chief executive officer when Hohn retires next April; Sternberg will retain his title as president; photo (M)
